questions.question_text_1:
Slipline Co. requires 1500 units of plastic ribbon per month. Each plastic ribbon costs Rs. 27 in the market. Placing an order costs Rs. 150 to Slipline Co. and the inventory carrying charges work out to 20% of the unit ribbon cost per year. 
Based on the above data, answer the given subquestions.
question_texts:
Slipline Co. requires 1500 units of plastic ribbon per month. Each plastic ribbon costs Rs. 27 in the market. Placing an order costs Rs. 150 to Slipline Co. and the inventory carrying charges work out to 20% of the unit ribbon cost per year. 
Based on the above data, answer the given subquestions.

questions.question_text_1: What should be the order quantity which minimizes the total cost to Slipline Co.
question_texts: What should be the order quantity which minimizes the total cost to Slipline Co.

questions.question_text_1: Ramu puts up a stall for Diwali Light (Diya) every year. He builds a Diya at a cost of Rs. 1 and earns Rs.2 by selling each Diya. Any Diya not sold by Diwali will be discounted to 50 Paisa. From his experience, Ramu knows that the demand is Uniformly Distributed within [800, 1000] units. Then answer the given subquestions.
question_texts: Ramu puts up a stall for Diwali Light (Diya) every year. He builds a Diya at a cost of Rs. 1 and earns Rs.2 by selling each Diya. Any Diya not sold by Diwali will be discounted to 50 Paisa. From his experience, Ramu knows that the demand is Uniformly Distributed within [800, 1000] units. Then answer the given subquestions.

questions.question_text_1: Govind needs to visit City-7. Currently he is stationed at City-1. He has a few alternative routes denoted by the arrows (arcs). There are other cities viz. 2, 3, 4, 5, 6 which falls on various routes between City-1 and City-7. The weights on the arcs represents the distances between respective nodes. However, there is no connection between City-2 and City-6. This scenario is represented in Fig-1.
questions.question_text_2:
Govind needs to visit City-7. Currently he is stationed at City-1. He has a few alternative routes denoted by the arrows (arcs). There are other cities viz. 2, 3, 4, 5, 6 which falls on various routes between City-1 and City-7. The weights on the arcs represents the distances between respective nodes. However, there is no connection between City-2 and City-6. This scenario is represented in Fig-1. 
  You need to apply dynamic programming (backward recursion) to identify the shortest route. Answer the given sub-questions:

props.summary:
### Summary of Core Topics, Concepts, Principles, and Equations

#### 1. **Inventory Management**
- **Economic Order Quantity (EOQ):**
  - Formula: \( Q = \sqrt{\frac{2DS}{H}} \)
  - Where:
    - \( D \) is the annual demand.
    - \( S \) is the ordering cost per order.
    - \( H \) is the holding cost per unit per year.
- **Costs:**
  - **Ordering Cost:** Cost associated with placing an order.
  - **Holding Cost:** Cost associated with storing inventory.
  - **Shortage Cost:** Cost associated with not having enough inventory to meet demand.
    - Includes loss of customer goodwill, cost of losing a customer, and loss of profit.

#### 2. **Forecasting Models**
- **Exponential Smoothing:**
  - Formula: \( F_{t+1} = \alpha D_t + (1 - \alpha) F_t \)
  - Where:
    - \( F_t \) is the forecast for period \( t \).
    - \( D_t \) is the actual data for period \( t \).
    - \( \alpha \) is the smoothing factor.

#### 3. **Time Series Forecasting**
- **Primary Tasks:**
  - Identifying patterns.
  - Discovering relationships among variables of interest.

#### 4. **IoT Principles**
- **7 Principles of IoT:**
  - Big Analog Data
  - Constant Connection
  - Real-Time
  - Spectrum of Insights
  - (Note: Quality Control is not a principle of IoT)

#### 5. **Dynamic Programming**
- **Shortest Path Problem:**
  - **State Variable:** Represents the beginning city in every stage.
  - **Action Set:** Represents the city to visit next in a stage.
  - **Objective Function:** Minimizes the total distance or cost.

#### 6. **Uniform Distribution and Critical Ratio**
- **Critical Ratio:**
  - Formula: \( \frac{\text{Profit}}{\text{Profit} + \text{Loss}} \)
  - Used in decision-making under uncertainty.
- **Optimal Order Quantity:**
  - Determined based on demand distribution and cost parameters.

### Knowledge Graph 

```mermaid
graph TD;
    A[Inventory Management] --> B[Economic Order Quantity]
    A --> C[Costs]
    B --> D[Formula: Q = sqrt(2DS/H)]
    C --> E[Ordering Cost]
    C --> F[Holding Cost]
    C --> G[Shortage Cost]
    G --> H[Loss of Customer Goodwill]
    G --> I[Cost of Losing a Customer]
    G --> J[Loss of Profit]

    K[Forecasting Models] --> L[Exponential Smoothing]
    L --> M[Formula: F_{t+1} = αD_t + (1-α)F_t]

    N[Time Series Forecasting] --> O[Identifying Patterns]
    N --> P[Discovering Relationships]

    Q[IoT Principles] --> R[Big Analog Data]
    Q --> S[Constant Connection]
    Q --> T[Real-Time]
    Q --> U[Spectrum of Insights]

    V[Dynamic Programming] --> W[Shortest Path Problem]
    W --> X[State Variable]
    W --> Y[Action Set]
    W --> Z[Objective Function]

    AA[Uniform Distribution] --> AB[Critical Ratio]
    AA --> AC[Optimal Order Quantity]
```

### Additional Knowledge Graph for Specific Concepts

```mermaid
graph TD;
    A[Economic Order Quantity] --> B[Annual Demand]
    A --> C[Ordering Cost]
    A --> D[Holding Cost]
    B --> E[Estimated Value]
    B --> F[Actual Value]
    C --> G[Estimated Value]
    C --> H[Actual Value]
    D --> I[Estimated Value]
    D --> J[Actual Value]

    K[Exponential Smoothing] --> L[Forecast]
    K --> M[Actual Data]
    K --> N[Smoothing Factor]

    O[Shortest Path Problem] --> P[Graph Representation]
    P --> Q[Nodes]
    P --> R[Edges]
    P --> S[Weights]
```

This summary and the knowledge graphs should help you understand the core topics and their relationships, making it easier to prepare for the exam.
